repnme.cdata!:
Burkina Faso - First, Second, Third,
            Fourth, Fifth, Sixth Poverty Reduction Support Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the First, Second, and Third
            Poverty Reduction Credit Project (PRSC) for Burkina Faso are
            as follows: outcomes of the project were satisfactory,
            sustainability is likely, and the performance of the Bank
            and the Borrower was also rated satisfactory. Ratings for
            the Fourth, Fifth, and Sixth Poverty Reduction Credit
            Project for Burkina Faso are as follows: outcomes of the
            project were satisfactory, sustainability is moderate, and
            the performance of the Bank and the Borrower was also rated
            satisfactory. The lessons learned from the report are: 1)
            PRSCs are useful instruments to help the borrower assume
            increased responsibility in managing its public resources in
            an efficient manner, notably by providing more flexibility
            and predictability; however, there is a risk of complacency
            and of dependence on continued foreign budget support; 2)
            issues of attribution are inevitable when the reform
            programs are supported by several donors; 3) since outcomes
            are to be assessed after several years, the quality of the
            relevant statistical data is critical; if insufficient,
            preparation should include remedial actions, including the
            selection and definition of baseline data; 4) since reforms
            are of medium-to long-term nature, early identification of
            institutional weaknesses and capacity constraints is of
            paramount importance; and 5) to assess outcome of a
            medium-term program, it is essential that the different
            documents of a PRSC series be consistent in content and
            format, including statistical series and other data.

repnme.cdata!:
Burkina Faso - Poverty Reduction Support
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings are as follows: Project
            outcome is satisfactory; sustainability is likely;
            institutional development impact is substantial; World Bank
            performance is satisfactory; and Borrower performance is
            satisfactory. A finding and Implication for subsequent
            operation(s) was identified as follows:  The program
            document recognized that external financial assistance is
            more effective when provided at the start of the
            Government's fiscal year, so that support is known in
            advance to be available and can be used as a basis for
            making budget management more predictable. Although this
            project was provided in the middle of the Government's
            fiscal year, it was expected that the other two projects in
            the series would be timed to fit better with the budget cycle.

repnme.cdata!:
Burkina Faso - Poverty Reduction Support
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Poverty Reduction Support Credit for
            Burkina Faso is designed to support the government's
            poverty reduction strategy as set out in the June 2000
            Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper (PRSP). The reform paper
            focuses on improving basic service delivery. This
            one-tranche operation would be the first of a planned series
            of three PRSCs with a total amount of US$120 million
            equivalent, prepared annually within a rolling, three-year
            horizon. The credit provides financial support tp allow the
            government to carry out its poverty reduction expenditure
            program expeditiously and fully. By focusing on economy-wide
            policy and institutional issues like broad public sector
            reform, the PRSC is expected to help implement the poverty
            reduction program in two ways. First, in the short run, the
            credit helps maintain macroeconomic stability and creates
            the conditions for accelerating growth by providing
            quick-disbursing assistance in the context of slow growth
            and lower-than-expected government revenues. Secondly, the
            program associated with the credit helps poverty reduction
            by improving the targeting and effectiveness of public
            expenditures to the poor and actually channeling public
            funds to more accountable local spending agencies. By
            improving the availability and efficient use of public
            resources for basic public services, and by stressing
            delegation, accountability, and transparency in budget
            management, the reform program should improve access to and
            the quality of these services.
